update.description:
This program requires two YAML files (test files are included in yaml/ ). The first file contains a list of teams, with the team information (name, timezone, CloudSim constellation, ...). The second file contains a list of tasks with its information (title, latency, uplink, local times to start/stop the task, ...). For each team, this program performs the next operations:

  1. Create a sequence of tasks according to the YAML task file and team file.
  2. Convert the local start/stop times to UTC.
  3. Upload a JSON file containing the tasks into the Team's CloudSim.
  4. Load the set of tasks into the Redis DB running on the Team's CloudSim.

How can I test this tool using Amazon?

  1. Run CloudSim on your local machine.
  2. Connect to your local CloudSim and start two new CloudSim constellations (CS-01, CS-02).
  3. Connect to CS-01 and start a new simulator constellation (Sim-01).
  4. Connect to CS-02 and start a new simulator constellation (Sim-02).
  5. Each team should have a CloudSim and a simulator constellation associated. Update teams.yaml with the constellation IDs for each team.
  6. Run ./bin/send_tasks.py <teams_file> <tasks_file>
  7. A new task list should appear on each Team's CloudSim.
update.title: send_tasks.py : A command line tool for loading tasks into a list of constellations

content.raw: There are three calls here to ssh.upload_file and ssh.cmd which I believe can trigger a SshClientException, it would be nice to have a proper handle for them.

content.raw: Are we silently failing here? Is expected that a team can not have a valid constellation up and running when the script is executed? If it's not expected, we have several options: warning message, error message or error code if it should never happen.
content.html: Are we silently failing here? Is expected that a team can not have a valid constellation up and running when the script is executed? If it's not expected, we have several options: warning message, error message or error code if it should never happen.

content.raw:
Those users are just for testing but yes, it is a good idea to test with different timezones. All of the available timezones are listed under the TZ* column here:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_zoneinfo_time_zones
content.html: Those users are just for testing but yes, it is a good idea to test with different timezones. All of the available timezones are listed under the TZ* column here: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_zoneinfo_time_zones
